author: By Claire Cain Miller
title: How Four Years Shaped Girls’ Political Views
description: After Hillary Clinton’s loss and a tumultuous presidency, I reconnected with teens I had interviewed to get their sense of the world.
content: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Live Webinar: Supporting Independent Reading and Writing
description: Join us on May 6 as we introduce our Summer Reading Contest and discuss ways to keep teenagers reading and writing all season long.
content: Providing students “voice and choice” is at the core of our annual Summer Reading Contest, in which we invite teenagers to let their interests guide their exploration of The New York Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard C. Paddock and Muktita Suhartono
title: Thailand’s prime minister is fined for not wearing a mask.
description: With Thailand struggling to bring its worst coronavirus outbreak under control, Bangkok made it compulsory for residents to wear masks in public beginning on Monday. One of the first to break the new rule?
content: With Thailand struggling to bring its worst coronavirus outbreak under control, Bangkok made it compulsory for residents to wear masks in public beginning on Monday. One of the first to break the new rule?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard C. Paddock and Muktita Suhartono
title: Indonesian General Is Killed in Rebel Ambush, Sparking Fears of Retaliation
description: President Joko Widodo announced the death of the high ranking intelligence chief and called for the arrest of rebel gunmen. Activists said they feared reprisals against Indigenous Papuans.
content: Indonesia’s top intelligence official in Papua Province was a one-star general who did not believe in leading from his office. A Bali native, Brig. Gen. I Gusti Putu Danny Karya Nugraha rose through the ranks of Indonesia’s feared special forces and often went on patrol with troops in areas where separatist rebels were known to stage attacks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: Inside Anthony Hopkins’s Unexpected Win at the Oscars
description: The actor offered to accept via Zoom but the academy said no. Still, he won because of a release strategy that ensured his film would peak at the last minute.
content: For months, it was considered a sure bet that Chadwick Boseman would win a posthumous best-actor Oscar for his galvanizing performance in “Ma Rainey’s Black Bottom.” The Sunday night ceremony was even rearranged around that expected outcome, scheduling Boseman’s category last so his widow, Simone Ledward Boseman, could accept and end the show with a crescendo of emotion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel E. Gross
title: They Call It a ‘Women’s Disease.’ She Wants to Redefine It.
description: As a bioengineer, Linda Griffith once grew a human ear on the back of a mouse. Now she is reframing endometriosis as a key to unlocking some of biology’s greatest secrets.
content: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — Most labs devoted to women’s diseases are accompanied by obvious symbols of womanhood: a rose, a tulip, an hourglass silhouette. Not Linda Griffith’s. Tucked away in the building for biological engineering, the M.I.T. Center for Gynepathology Research is marked only by the letters CGR in red and black, the G formed from a curved arrow representing the hand of the engineer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler
title: Campaign to Recall Gov. Gavin Newsom Qualifies for California Ballot
description: The 1.6 million voters who signed a petition for the Republican-led recall effort have 30 business days to ask to have their names removed if they so choose.
content: SACRAMENTO — Fueled by partisan fury and a backlash against pandemic shutdowns, a Republican-led campaign to oust Gov. Gavin Newsom of California has officially qualified for the ballot, officials said on Monday, setting the stage for the second recall election in the state’s history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Weise
title: Microsoft reports strongest quarterly growth in years, as profit also rises.
description: “Digital adoption curves aren’t slowing down,” Satya Nadella, Microsoft’s chief executive, said in a statement. “They’re accelerating.”
content: Microsoft on Tuesday reported that its quarterly sales grew at one of its strongest rates in years, as the company was poised to cross $2 trillion in market value.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier
title: 2 Spanish Journalists Among 3 Killed in Ambush in Burkina Faso
description: The journalists were filming a documentary about anti-poaching activities in the Western African nation when their convoy was ambushed.
content: Two Spanish journalists making a documentary about anti-poaching efforts and a third foreign national were killed in Burkina Faso after being kidnapped there on Monday, according to the authorities from the Western African nation and Spain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Kessler
title: Another tech company bans employees from talking politics at work.
description: The announcement by Basecamp, a company that makes productivity software, follows a surge of employee activism and corporate action on social issues.
content: Basecamp, a company that makes productivity software, said on Monday that it had “made some internal changes,” including a ban on talking about politics at work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth A. Harris and Alexandra Alter
title: ‘There Is a Tension There’: Publishers Draw Fire for Signing Trump Officials
description: Kellyanne Conway, Mike Pence and William Barr have book deals. That is raising new challenges for publishers trying to balance ideological lines with a desire to continue representing the political spectrum.
content: Things were already strained at Simon & Schuster.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Caryn Rabin, Emily Anthes and Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: Vaccinated Americans don’t need masks outdoors in small groups or when biking and running, the C.D.C. says.
description: Because the risk of infection is much lower outdoors, health officials also relaxed advice for those who haven’t gotten their shots, saying they could safely shed their masks for some outside activities.
content: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention took a major step on Tuesday toward coaxing Americans into a post-pandemic world, relaxing the rules on mask wearing outdoors as coronavirus cases recede and people increasingly chafe against restrictions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Schulten
title: What Have You Learned About Friendship This Year?
description: Did the pandemic shrink your social circle — or just clarify who is most important to you and why?
content: How did the pandemic affect your friendships?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives and Muktita Suhartono
title: Weeks Before Fatal Descent, Indonesia Submarine Crew Sang Unwitting Farewell
description: A video of the sailors singing went viral on social media, prompting many to infer a hidden meaning in the pop song’s lyrics.
content: Below deck on their submarine, Indonesian sailors crowded around a crewman with a guitar and crooned a pop song called “Till We Meet Again.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Rubinstein and J. David Goodman
title: A $7 Billion Mistake? New York Seeks to Curb New Hotels.
description: A plan to require approval for every new hotel has sparked opposition inside city government, where budget officials say it could reduce future tax revenue from tourism.
content: Mayor Bill de Blasio and other New York City leaders are pushing a controversial plan to drastically restrict hotel development, a move that the mayor’s own experts fear could endanger the city’s post-pandemic recovery and cost billions in lost tax revenue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Veranda, From George Mendes of Aldea, Opens in SoHo
description: Reservations open for Daniel Boulud’s Le Pavillon, Manresa at Intersect by Lexus, and more restaurant news.
content: George Mendes, the chef who enlivened menus at Aldea and Lupulo with Portuguese flavors, is back at the stove. He closed Lupulo more than three years ago and Aldea a little over a year ago after a 10-year run, because he felt that he needed a break. Now, he will be the chef and a partner at this new SoHo restaurant. He will be running it with David Rabin, a hospitality veteran who is also a partner in the Lambs Club, the new Sona and others. “I always knew I’d be back,” Mr. Mendes said. “I’ve spent the past year cooking at home, baking sourdough and exploring new flavors, and I’m ready to translate them to a restaurant.” Veranda is in the new ModernHaus hotel, a property that was the James, and has been completely reconfigured. Veranda’s main dining room is up from the street, and designed in greenhouse fashion with a retractable ceiling. It’s surrounded by outdoor seating on an upper terrace and a multilevel garden. Mr. Mendes’s menu is global but lightly strewn with Portuguese touches. Think flor de sal (fleur de sel) and olive oil for the sourdough bread, salt cod croquettes, Goan curry for shrimp, and a piri piri marinade used on grilled chicken. Chicken rice is his take on paella. He also delivers seasonality with all the green stuff you hunger for right now. “I’ve been cooking farm-to-table since I worked at Bouley and in France,” he said. “The bounty is incredible now.” A number of products, including the sourdough bread, are sold to take home. (Opens Friday)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete Wells
title: Pleasures and Prescriptions of the West African Diet, at Nneji
description: At a takeout shop in Queens, egusi and red stew come with a message about nourishment.
content: The last time I picked up dinner from Nneji, a small shop in Queens that sells African products and food for takeout, something new was hidden under one of the steel lids that cover steaming pans of marigold-yellow wilted onions, glossy red tomatoes stewed with a cow foot or two, lumps of goat that have taken in by osmosis the sweetness and power of several different peppers, and other long-simmered West African pleasures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Benner
title: Justice Dept. Asked to Examine Whether Swiss Bank Kept Helping Tax Dodgers
description: Credit Suisse had admitted to helping American clients evade taxes in 2014 and was fined $2.6 billion, but it avoided even higher fines because of its vow that it had stopped the practice.
content: WASHINGTON — The chairman of the Senate finance panel asked Attorney General Merrick B. Garland on Tuesday for information about whether Credit Suisse continued to help rich Americans defraud the I.R.S. even after it signed a settlement agreement with the Justice Department vowing to stop the practice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Irwin
title: Automatic Aid for the People? How Jobless Benefits Can Fit the Economy.
description: The pandemic showed the flaws in the American approach to help the unemployed. Alternatives exist.
content: For years, people who study unemployment benefits have warned that the American system of jobless insurance was too antiquated and clunky to meet the needs of workers in a time of economic crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley
title: Biden aims to recoup over $700 billion in unpaid taxes by beefing up the I.R.S.
description: The recouped funds would be used to help pay for the president’s $1.5 trillion American Families Plan, which he will detail before addressing a joint session of Congress on Wednesday.
content: President Biden is expected to propose giving the Internal Revenue Service an extra $80 billion and more authority over the next 10 years as he looks for ways to raise money to pay for his economic agenda, according to two people familiar with the plan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: Rights Group Hits Israel With Explosive Charge: Apartheid
description: Human Rights Watch is the latest watchdog to accuse Israel of perpetuating a version of the racist legal system that once governed South Africa. Israel says the charge is baseless.
content: JERUSALEM — When hundreds of rights groups gathering in South Africa in 2001 accused Israel of apartheid, some participants distanced themselves from the accusation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich
title: Fox News fights an election company’s defamation suit with a new court filing.
description: Fox is asking a court to dismiss a suit filed by Smartmatic, which accused it and three of its anchors of promoting falsehoods about the company.
content: In the months since the election tech company Smartmatic sued Fox News and three of its anchors, the two companies have engaged in a prehearing back-and-forth that continued Monday when Fox filed briefs in support of a previous motion to have the lawsuit dismissed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Times Event: How to Save Ourselves From Disinformation
description: Comedian Sarah Silverman and The Times’s Kevin Roose, Sheera Frenkel and Davey Alba explore how disinformation spreads, and how we can fight back.
content: Times subscribers can R.S.V.P. for this free event on Wednesday, May 26 at 7 p.m. Eastern, 4 p.m. Pacific.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Late Night Wraps Up This Year’s Academy Awards
description: “The ratings for the Oscars plummeted from 23 million last year to less than 10 million this year. How can something so woke put so many people to sleep?” Jimmy Kimmel joked on Monday.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. We’re all stuck at home at the moment, so here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ron Lieber
title: How Identity Thieves Took My Wife for a Ride
description: Auto insurers try to make it easy to sign up for a policy. Those efforts have given an opening to scammers.
content: The first sign of trouble was the arrival of envelopes from the New York State Department of Labor, all about my wife’s previous earnings and recent unemployment filing. The second was the cheery “Welcome to Progressive” package, telling her how great it was to have her with the company now that she had bought her new auto insurance policy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Kolomatsky
title: The Best (and Worst) States for Remote Work
description: A recent study ranked all 50 states and Washington, D.C., to find where working from home was most attractive to workers and employers.
content: With attitudes and policies around remote work changing rapidly, workers across the country are beginning to ask themselves an exciting question: If I could work from home forever, where would I live?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Part Victory Lap, Part Sales Job: Biden to Address Joint Session of Congress
description: The president will mark the nearly 100 days he has spent in the Oval Office by describing his efforts to vaccinate Americans and revive the economy.
content: WASHINGTON — A perk of the presidency is the chance to deliver a speech to Congress, and millions of Americans, soon after taking office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin and Jade-Snow Joachim
title: Masks, India, Tulips: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Biden to nominate Texas sheriff to lead Immigration and Customs Enforcement.
description: Ed Gonzalez would take over an agency that has not had a permanent leader since 2017.
content: President Biden will nominate Ed Gonzalez, a sheriff from Texas and critic of the Trump administration’s deportation policies, to lead Immigration and Customs Enforcement, the White House said on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Levin
title: No Burning Man festival again this year because of the pandemic, organizers say.
description: After months of cautious (and optimistic) planning, organizers of the annual festival in Nevada’s Black Rock Desert decided against holding it.
content: Burning Man, the annual countercultural arts event that typically draws tens of thousands of people to Nevada’s Black Rock Desert, has been canceled again this year because of the pandemic, but will return in 2022, organizers announced on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Brennan
title: Why Biden Must Watch This Palestinian Movie
description: Children in the West Bank and Gaza grow up feeling that their fate is controlled by people who don't care about them.
content: On a recent evening I watched “The Present,” a short film by Farah Nabulsi, a Palestinian filmmaker, which was nominated for an Academy Award for live-action short film. (The winner in the category was “Two Distant Strangers.”) Ms. Nabulsi’s 25-minute film is a powerful, heartbreaking account of the travails of Yusuf, a Palestinian man, and Yasmine, his young daughter, as they traverse an Israeli military checkpoint in the West Bank twice in a single day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luis Ferré-Sadurní
title: No more ‘Cuomo chips.’ New York’s legislature will suspend a rule that required food to be ordered with alcohol.
description: The rule had been criticized by many, including the restaurant industry and many Republican lawmakers, as arbitrary and an unfair regulation for bars that weren’t used to serving food.
content: The leaders of the New York State Legislature said Tuesday they would move on the next day to suspend a  pandemic directive that required customers to order food when purchasing alcohol at bars and restaurants.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Alter and Jennifer Schuessler
title: Norton Takes Philip Roth Biography Out of Print
description: The publisher also said it would make a donation to sexual abuse organizations equal to the advance it paid Blake Bailey, the author accused of sexual assault.
content: W.W. Norton said in a memo to its staff on Tuesday that it will permanently take Blake Bailey’s biography of Philip Roth out of print, following allegations that Mr. Bailey sexually assaulted multiple women and behaved inappropriately toward his students when he was an eighth grade English teacher.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: India’s terrifying second wave.
content: “Crematories are so full of bodies, it’s as if a war just happened. Fires burn around the clock. Many places are holding mass cremations, dozens at a time, and at night, in certain areas of New Delhi, the sky glows.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: A study in Oklahoma that funded college accounts for newborns is showing promise.
description: An experiment called SEED for Oklahoma Kids, or SEED OK, is one of a growing number of efforts by cities and states — governed by Democrats and Republicans alike — to help a new generation climb the educational ladder and build assets
content: An experiment called SEED for Oklahoma Kids, or SEED OK, is one of a growing number of efforts by cities and states — governed by Democrats and Republicans alike — to help a new generation climb the educational ladder and build assets
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marilyn Stasio
title: When Teacups, Burning Lumps of Coal and Eggs Flew Through the Air
description: In her delightfully spooky new book, “The Haunting of Alma Fielding,” Kate Summerscale investigates poltergeist activity in 1930s London.
content: THE HAUNTING OF ALMA FIELDINGA True Ghost StoryBy Kate Summerscale
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas L. Friedman
title: Is There a War Coming Between China and the U.S.?
description: A new novel about 2034 has unnerving echoes of today’s headlines.
content: If you’re looking for a compelling beach read this summer, I recommend the novel “2034,” by James Stavridis, a retired admiral, and Elliot Ackerman, a former Marine and intelligence officer. The book is about how China and America go to war in 2034, beginning with a naval battle near Taiwan and with China acting in a tacit alliance with Iran and Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Sisson
title: How Data Is Changing the Way Offices Are Run
description: Building owners are using data collection and artificial intelligence to help control systems like heating, lighting, air quality and even the flow of workers.
content: Developers are harnessing a growing obsession with data to improve office buildings in ways that could cut costs and streamline operations, saving owners millions of dollars annually.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Moskin
title: The Island Is Idyllic. As a Workplace, It’s Toxic.
description: Globe-trotting diners flock to the Willows Inn’s serene Northwest setting. But former employees say faked ingredients, sexual harassment and an abusive kitchen are the real story.
content: The chef Blaine Wetzel first came to Lummi, a tiny island near the San Juan archipelago of Washington State, in 2010. At age 24, he was fresh off a two-year stint at the vaunted Copenhagen restaurant Noma. He could have found a job in any kitchen in the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Sondheim Musical, in Development for Years, Looks Unlikely
description: The 91-year-old composer told the Public Theater last year that he was no longer working on a show based on the films of Luis Buñuel.
content: One big lingering question for theater fans following the news that the prolific producer Scott Rudin will “step back” from his stage projects: What will happen to his shows in development, notably the Stephen Sondheim musical “Buñuel,” which at last report was slated to be produced Off Broadway at the Public Theater?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanne Timmons
title: Baby Mammoths Were Meals for These Saber-Tooth Cats
description: Fossils from a Texas site suggest that the predatory felines not only snatched mammoths from their herds, but dragged the remains back to their cave.
content: On a landscape that would one day become a suburb of San Antonio, paleontologists paint a picture that is as bloody as it is fascinating.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Baker
title: After Nearly a Year of Unrest, Portland Leaders Pursue a Crackdown
description: Mayor Ted Wheeler said he wanted to “unmask” demonstrators who engaged in property destruction. The Oregon city has seen regular demonstrations since the murder of George Floyd.
content: PORTLAND, Ore. — After the protests have concluded, sometimes in the early morning hours, Margaret Carter finds herself climbing into her gray Toyota Camry and cruising the streets of Portland so she can see the latest damage for herself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: There’s an Art to Making Your Bed
description: You can start by disregarding thread count. Here’s what else the pros know that you may not.
content: If you want your bedroom to serve as a refuge from daily stress, one piece of furniture is more important than all the rest: the bed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Suderman
title: The Republican Party Is Failing in Too Many Ways
description: Americans have been left without a credible opposition to a big expansion of federal power under Biden.
content: Have you heard about the Republican arguments against President Biden’s economic plans? Me neither.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daisuke Wakabayashi
title: Alphabet’s profit more than doubled last quarter as Google’s advertising business rebounded.
description: Alphabet posted revenue of $55.31 billion, up 34 percent from a year earlier, and net profit more than doubled to $17.93 billion in the first quarter.
content: Google’s parent company, Alphabet, said on Tuesday that revenue in its most recent quarter increased sharply from the same period a year ago, boosted by strong demand for online advertising on its search results and YouTube videos and by continued growth at its cloud computing arm.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley, Nicholas Fandos and Farnaz Fassihi
title: John Kerry denies ever having discussed Israeli strikes in Syria with Iran’s foreign minister.
description: In a leaked recording of a phone conversation, Mohammad Javad Zarif said Mr. Kerry, a secretary of state under President Barack Obama, had informed him that Israel had attacked Iranian interests in Syria at least 200 times.
content: John Kerry, a former secretary of state, said on Monday that he had never discussed covert Israeli airstrikes in Syria with Iran’s foreign minister, Mohammad Javad Zarif, contrary to Mr. Zarif’s claim in a leaked conversation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stacy Cowley
title: A new restaurant grant fund opening Monday is expected to be exhausted in the priority period.
description: All eligible businesses will be able to apply for the $29 billion program starting on Monday, but only claims from the priority groups will be approved in the first three weeks.
content: A $28.6 billion grant fund for restaurants, bars, caterers and other food businesses will open Monday, the government said on Tuesday, offering an extra lifeline to some of America’s hardest hit small businesses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley and Alan Rappeport
title: Biden Seeks $80 Billion to Beef Up I.R.S. Audits of High-Earners
description: The president’s “American Families Plan,” which he will detail this week, will be offset in part by a tax enforcement effort that administration officials believe will raise $700 billion over a decade.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden, looking to pay for his ambitious economic agenda and shift more of the nation’s tax burden to the wealthy, will propose giving the Internal Revenue Service an extra $80 billion and more authority over the next 10 years to help crack down on tax evasion by high-earners and large corporations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffrey Gettleman and Atul Loke
title: ‘This Is a Catastrophe.’ In India, Illness Is Everywhere.
description: As India suffers the world’s worst coronavirus crisis, our New Delhi bureau chief describes the fear of living amid a disease spreading at such scale and speed.
content: NEW DELHI — Crematories are so full of bodies, it’s as if a war just happened. Fires burn around the clock. Many places are holding mass cremations, dozens at a time, and at night, in certain areas of New Delhi, the sky glows.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Kimmelman
title: A Billion-Dollar Battle Over a Parking Lot at the Seaport
description: For decades, development of a scruffy lot on the edge of the South Street historic district has divided residents. Now our critic supports a new plan.
content: The other morning I boarded a No. 2 train to check out a parking lot at the South Street Seaport Historic District.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manuela Andreoni and Bryan Pietsch
title: Brazil’s health authority rejects importing Russia’s Sputnik V vaccine.
description: RIO DE JANEIRO — Brazil’s health authority said late Monday that it would not recommend importing Sputnik V, the Covid-19 vaccine developed by Russia.
content: RIO DE JANEIRO — Brazil’s health authority said late Monday that it would not recommend importing Sputnik V, the Covid-19 vaccine developed by Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Transgender and Nonbinary Teens Share Their Stories in New Book Series
description: Written by four teenagers, the books aim to open up conversations about young people who are transgender or nonbinary.
content: Gia Parr has always dreamed of returning to her elementary school one day to help its students and staff understand who transgender people are.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: A Population Bust
description: We look at the upsides and downsides of slow population growth in the U.S.
content: The U.S. population grew by only 7.4 percent over the past decade, the smallest increase since the 1930s, the Census Bureau reported yesterday. This morning, I want to explain why and talk about both the upsides and downsides of slower population growth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: ‘Yo, V.I.P., Let’s Kick It!’
description: “10th century Holy Roman Emperor.”
content: TUESDAY PUZZLE — As the weather warms in my part of the country, I like to start thinking about refreshing things that I can serve my family as we spend more time outside. We’re not yet at the point in the pandemic where I can fantasize about having a group of people over for a party, but — for now — my inner Amy Sedaris is happy focusing on the people in my little bubble.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: At Real Madrid, the Only Trophy That Counts Can Still Slip Away
description: A history of Champions League success is part of the fabric at Real Madrid. No club has won it more often. But rivals keep driving up the price.
content: Real Madrid knows the route. The first stop will be at Almudena, the Spanish capital’s cathedral. Then it is on to Puerta del Sol, in the heart of the city, before a reception at the Palace of Communications, where the local council sits. The formalities over, it is out on to Plaza de Cibeles, the fountain-cum-roundabout where Real Madrid always celebrates its triumphs.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Can the U.S. Win Back Its Climate Credibility?
description: At a summit he convened, the president discovered how difficult it will be to  re-establish America as an environmental leader.
content: It wasn’t quite how he imagined it on the campaign trail, but  last week President Biden held his long-promised global climate summit, attended by leaders from all over the world, via video link.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Perlroth
title: Daniel Kaminsky, Internet Security Savior, Dies at 42
description: If you are reading this obituary online, you owe your digital safety to him.
content: Daniel Kaminsky, a security researcher known for his discovery of a fundamental flaw in the fabric of the internet, died on Friday at his home in San Francisco. He was 42.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Monika Pronczuk
title: Greek Neo-Nazi Lawmaker Stripped of Immunity by European Parliament
description: Ioannis Lagos, sentenced to 13 years in prison by a Greek court for his part in running the fascist Golden Dawn party, had been immune from extradition as an elected member of the European Union’s legislature.
content: BRUSSELS — The convicted Greek neo-Nazi Ioannis Lagos was stripped of his immunity as a member of the European Parliament on Tuesday, clearing the way for his extradition to Greece months after he was sentenced in a landmark trial.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: South Korea Loved Her Long Before Hollywood
description: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, April 27, 2021.
content: “The producers said they would eat their hat if I would make it as an actress. Unfortunately, they are all dead now.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Hess
title: When Vaccines Become an Internet Personality Test
description: It feels very American to turn the vaccine rollout into a branding spectacle rooted in the worship of pharmaceutical companies.
content: What is your favorite piece of vaccine-related content? Mine is a TikTok that goes like this: An adult man smiles assuredly at an imaginary group positioned outside the frame. “OK, I’ll see you tomorrow,” he tells them, then swivels to whisper urgently into a phone pressed to his ear. Suddenly his eyeballs are glazed with tears. “Mom, can you come get me,” he pleads. “Yeah, ’cause I freaking hate it here. I’ve been working so hard and I make one mistake and now everyone is like, trying to cancel me. Yeah, and Moderna and Pfizer,” he continues, are the meanest people “I’ve ever met.” A text box tacked to the screen identifies the man as “Johnson & Johnson.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: sublime
description: This word has appeared in 149 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: The City of London plans to convert empty offices into homes.
description: The City of London, the square mile in the center of London that is the heart of Britain’s financial and legal services, once had more than half a million daily commuters bustling through its streets. But the coronavirus pandemic has ushered in a new era of working from home that risks leaving the area permanently depleted. The City of London Corporation, its governing body, is looking for ways to revive it.
content: The City of London, the square mile in the center of London that is the heart of Britain’s financial and legal services, once had more than half a million daily commuters bustling through its streets. But the coronavirus pandemic has ushered in a new era of working from home that risks leaving the area permanently depleted. The City of London Corporation, its governing body, is looking for ways to revive it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Cohen
title: College Accounts at Birth: State Efforts Raise New Hopes
description: Creating and seeding accounts for every newborn is found to have an impact on aspirations as well as savings.
content: Braylon Dedmon was 3 days old when his mother, Talasheia, was offered $1,000 to open a college savings account in his name.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lena Wilson
title: Live Your Gay Millennial Pandemic Fantasy in Stardew Valley
description: In the farming RPG, I can enjoy a life of pastoral domesticity. IRL, I’m a lesbian urbanite struggling through the pandemic.
content: Fed up with his soulless corporate job, a young man moves to the farm he inherited from his grandfather, where he joins a quaint community and meets his future husband. That’s not the plot of a new gay Hallmark movie — it’s the story of my pixelated alter ego in the video game Stardew Valley.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: Twitch, Where Far-Right Influencers Feel at Home
description: Barred from Twitter and Facebook as Trump was, social media’s younger conspiracy theorists are moving to Twitch.
content: What’s the biggest political surprise of 2021? Not the Democrats’ upset wins in Georgia, flipping the Senate in their favor. Not President Biden’s leftward swerve.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Markoff
title: These Materials Could Make Science Fiction a Reality
description: Metamaterials, which could improve smartphones and change how we use other technology, allow scientists to control light waves in new ways.
content: This article is part of our new series, Currents, which examines how rapid advances in technology are transforming our lives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush and Jim Tankersley
title: ‘Amtrak Joe’ will travel to Pa. to sell his infrastructure plan and celebrate his favorite mode of transportation.
description: President Biden will travel on Friday to attend Amtrak’s 50th anniversary celebration in Philadelphia where he will promote his infrastructure plan and celebrate his signature mode of transportation, the White House announced on Tuesday.
content: President Biden will travel on Friday to attend Amtrak’s 50th anniversary celebration in Philadelphia where he will promote his infrastructure plan and celebrate his signature mode of transportation, the White House announced on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning
title: Extremists Find a Financial Lifeline on Twitch
description: QAnon adherents and other far-right influencers are making thousands of dollars broadcasting election and vaccine conspiracy theories on the streaming site.
content: Terpsichore Maras-Lindeman, a podcaster who fought to overturn the 2020 presidential election, recently railed against mask mandates to her 4,000 fans in a live broadcast and encouraged them to enter stores maskless. On another day, she grew emotional while thanking them for sending her $84,000.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed Morales
title: Rubén Blades, a Salsa Legend, Swings in a Different Direction: Jazz
description: “Salswing!,” his new project with the Panamanian big band leader Roberto Delgado, celebrates the connections between Afro-Cuban music and jazz.
content: Rubén Blades is a renowned vocalist, one of the emblematic singer-songwriters of 1970s salsa. But he’s not always recognized for his achievements in other disciplines: He’s also a Broadway and Hollywood actor, a composer, a Harvard Law School master’s graduate and a one-time candidate for president of his native Panama. And don’t ever say he can’t sing a swing tune like Frank Sinatra or Tony Bennett.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Madeleine Thien
title: Jhumpa Lahiri’s New Novel Pares a Shrinking Life Down to Its Essence
description: In “Whereabouts,” an unnamed narrator in an unnamed Italian city mulls a contemplative existence devoid of intimate human contact.
content: WHEREABOUTS By Jhumpa Lahiri
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jolie Ruben, Amanda Webster and Raillan Brooks
title: Making Your Own Fun
description: Fun can take many forms. An end-of-day ice cream ritual. Caring for rescued chickens. A bubble bath for an inanimate friend. Three photographers show us what a good time means to them now.
content: Mark Sommerfeld found it in lockdown at his parents’ home in Ontario, where “there was an emphasis on big dinners, movies and games” like Jenga, he said. He also made his own fun in his Queens apartment: “Spontaneity, both simple and elaborate, is my new fun and has so far included juggling eggs, making a bubble bath for an inanimate friend, playing board games, reading in nature, sending snail mail.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anthony Tommasini
title: Theodore Lambrinos, Baritone With a Zest for the Road, Dies at 85
description: Mr. Lambrinos sang performances at the Metropolitan Opera and was a stalwart of New York Grand Opera. He died of Covid-related pneumonia.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anahad O'Connor
title: Can You Have Alcohol After the Covid Vaccine?
description: Moderate drinking is unlikely to impair the immune response to the Covid vaccine, but heavy drinking might.
content: After a long year and a lot of anticipation, getting the Covid-19 vaccine can be cause for celebration, which for some might mean pouring a drink and toasting to their new immunity. But can alcohol interfere with your immune response?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron E. Carroll
title: When Can We Declare the Pandemic Over?
description: Normal has never meant “perfectly safe.” A safer world will likely still have Covid-19 in it.
content: During the pandemic, good management and guidance have often been lacking. If we want to make our exit from the crisis better than our entrance and passage through it, we’ve got to start planning now. A good first step would be to agree on our definition of an ending.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lee Wolosky
title: Biden Has a Chance to Remedy One of Obama’s Biggest Regrets
description: Guantánamo is hugely expensive, and its detainees are increasingly geriatric and unlikely to return to the terrorist battlefield.
content: President Biden’s decision to fully withdraw U.S. troops from Afghanistan is a significant step toward extricating the United States not only from its longest war, but also from a massive national security architecture defined by the threat of foreign terrorism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Rubinstein and J. David Goodman
title: New York’s recovery depends partly on tourists, but a city plan aims to curb new hotel construction.
description: New York City leaders, led by Mayor Bill de Blasio, are closing in on a plan to drastically restrict hotel development, a move that the mayor’s own experts fear could endanger the city’s post-pandemic recovery.
content: New York City leaders, led by Mayor Bill de Blasio, are closing in on a plan to drastically restrict hotel development, a move that the mayor’s own experts fear could endanger the city’s post-pandemic recovery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset
title: Private Autopsy Shows Deputies Shot Andrew Brown Jr. 5 Times
description: The fatal shot was to the back of the head, lawyers for Mr. Brown’s family said. Cries are growing for the authorities in Elizabeth City, N.C., to release body camera footage.
content: ELIZABETH CITY, N.C. — Lawyers for the family of Andrew Brown Jr., who was shot and killed by sheriff’s deputies in coastal North Carolina last week, said on Tuesday that a private autopsy paid for by Mr. Brown’s family showed that he was hit by five bullets and killed by a shot to the back of the head.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wilson
title: The Biggest Mayor’s Race in Years? New Yorkers’ Minds Are Elsewhere.
description: Two months before the Democratic primary for mayor, arguably the most consequential New York City election in decades, many voters are focused on other things.
content: In Brooklyn’s Church of St. Mark on a recent Sunday, Arlene Punnett, 82, listened patiently as a special guest spoke of his hardworking mother and his years as a police officer. His name was Eric Adams, the Brooklyn borough president, and he had come to seek the church’s support in his run for mayor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Linda Villarosa
title: Black Lives Are Shorter in Chicago. My Family’s History Shows Why.
description: How did a Promised Land to generations of Black families become a community of lost lives?
content: On a wrinkled sheet of lined paper tucked in my mom’s purse was a list of places we had jotted down, memories to visit. It was January 2020, and my mother and I were on a trip to Chicago, to see the places from her past and my early childhood in and around the Englewood section of the city, where she was born and raised, and where I was, too, before we moved to Denver in 1969. As we drove south in our rental car, from Roosevelt University on South Michigan Avenue, where Mom attended college in the 1950s, toward what was called the Black Belt, I imagined myself as a 7-year-old sitting on the second-floor balcony of my great-aunt’s brick building on South Vernon Avenue, watching people bustle below. I would strain to hear my mother soaking in news and gossip from her aunties, their voices soft and Southern, before I was shooed away, warned to stay out of grown folks’ business.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danielle Braff
title: Receptions on Wheels: the Food Trucks Roll In
description: Some couples are mobilizing their wedding meals during the pandemic. Here are six trucks that will feed your wedding guests.
content: From raw oysters to lobster rolls to alcohol-infused ice-cream, food trucks deliver modernized, pandemic friendly wedding spreads.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Perlroth and Julian E. Barnes
title: D.C. Police Department Data Is Leaked in a Cyberattack
description: The department appears to be the third police force to be targeted in a ransomware attack in six weeks, and the 26th government agency hit this year.
content: Hacked data from the Washington, D.C., Police Department started leaking onto the internet on Monday, making it the third police department in the United States to be hit by cybercriminals in six weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bryan Pietsch
title: West Virginia will give $100 savings bonds to people 16 to 35 who get vaccinated.
description: The governor said he hoped the payments, which will come from federal stimulus money, would motivate younger residents to get inoculated.
content: West Virginia will give $100 savings bonds to 16- to 35-year-olds who get a Covid-19 vaccine, Gov. Jim Justice said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Sloss
title: 4 Things to Know When Choosing a Travel Agent
description: Even the most D.I.Y.-inclined travelers are considering working with a professional adviser these days. Here’s how.
content: So, you’re thinking about traveling again? You’re not alone. The pandemic may not be over, but the expansion of vaccine eligibility in the United States — hiccups, delays and pauses aside — plus the news that the European Union will be opening up to vaccinated travelers is inspiring many to plan a real-deal summer vacation, or even take the leap on booking bucket-list adventures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ezra Marcus
title: Are There More Tulips Than Usual This Year?
description: After a year of languishing, New York City is flourishing.
content: At a time of global investment mania, New Yorkers can’t seem to get enough of one of the world’s oldest speculative assets. They’re not buying, though. Just admiring.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Ole Anthony, Scourge of Televangelists, Dies at 82
description: After working as a well-paid Republican operative, he gave up a lavish lifestyle to live in poverty as a self-proclaimed Jeremiah, calling out fraud in the name of God.
content: Ole Anthony, a former Air Force intelligence specialist and Texas political operative who found Jesus in 1972, built a following among the down-and-out of east Dallas, and then used that movement to take down a rogue’s gallery of unscrupulous televangelists and faith healers, died on April 16 at a house in Dallas that he shared with several members of his organization, the Trinity Foundation. He was 82.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Shpigel
title: 2021 N.F.L. Draft: Trades Hint at Team Needs
description: San Francisco traded for the No. 3 pick to select a quarterback, and Baltimore traded into the first round, sending Orlando Brown to Kansas City, to reload for the future.
content: The top of the N.F.L. draft quaked late last month when the Miami Dolphins, the San Francisco 49ers and the Philadelphia Eagles swung what amounted to a three-team trade. The bottom of it shuddered on Friday when the Baltimore Ravens acquired another first-round pick.
source.name: The New York Times

title: New & Noteworthy, From Elizabeth Warren to Life as a Black Millennial
description: A selection of recent titles of interest; plus, a peek at what our colleagues around the newsroom are reading.
content: A BEGINNER’S GUIDE TO AMERICA: For the Immigrant and the Curious, by Roya Hakakian. (Knopf, $27.) This touching account by an Iranian-born poet details her adopted home’s quirks: money that all looks the same, well-stocked markets where the fruit has no smell.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘Why Can’t You Find Someone?’
description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
content: Tito asked me to marry him, but not for the happily ever after. He had AIDS — a death sentence in the early 1980s. He wanted his property to go to his partner, Michael, but his father disapproved. After Tito’s death, I was to wait a few years, then sign everything over to Michael. I was honored by Tito’s trust and might have said yes, but his father relented, allowing Michael to inherit Tito’s assets, though he would not be invited to the funeral. Forty years later, I miss my friend. Would he be married to Michael if he were alive? — Lynn Tamayo
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan
title: California Is Set to Lose a House Seat. What Now?
description: Tuesday: For the first time in California’s history, the state will lose congressional representation, based on new census data.
content: Good morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Pogrebin
title: Marie-Josée Kravis to Replace Leon Black as MoMA Chair
description: One month after Black, the embattled investor, said he would not stand for re-election, the museum chose its president emerita to replace him.
content: Just one month after the investor Leon Black said that he would not stand for re-election as the chairman of the Museum of Modern Art, the museum on Tuesday chose his replacement: Marie-Josée Kravis, 71, its president emerita.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Cedric Mullins and Matt Harvey Prove Too Much for Yankees
description: Baltimore moved one game ahead of the Yankees in the A.L. East. In May, New York stadiums can increase their capacity.
content: BALTIMORE — Cedric Mullins hit two home runs and a double, Matt Harvey pitched six impressive innings and the Baltimore Orioles beat the Yankees, 4-2, Monday night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Johnson
title: How Humanity Gave Itself an Extra Life
description: Between 1920 and 2020, the average human life span doubled. How did we do it? Science mattered — but so did activism.
content: In September 1918, a flu virus began spreading through Camp Devens, an overcrowded military base just outside Boston. By the end of the second week of the outbreak, one in five soldiers at the base had come down with the illness. But the speed with which it spread through the camp was not nearly as shocking as the lethality. “It is only a matter of a few hours then until death comes,” a camp physician wrote. “It is horrible. One can stand it to see one, two or 20 men die, but to see these poor devils dropping like flies sort of gets on your nerves. We have been averaging about 100 deaths per day.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Kornei
title: An Artist Sketches the Giant Gender Gap on the Moon
description: By drawing the small number of lunar craters named for women, an artist hopes to highlight women’s contributions to the sciences.
content: The moon’s surface is pockmarked with craters, the relics of violent impacts over cosmic time. A few of the largest are visible to the naked eye, and a backyard telescope reveals hundreds more. But turn astronomical observatories or even a space probe on our nearest celestial neighbor, and suddenly millions appear.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: Here’s My Novel Idea for the Republican Party
description: American politics needs more factions. The Republican senators floating populist proposals should forge one.
content: A few months ago, it was an open question whether once Donald Trump vacated the presidency, the idea of a more populist right-wing economic policy would disappear with him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Parul Sehgal
title: Alison Bechdel’s Latest Offers Familiar Pleasures in Brighter Colors
description: In “The Secret to Superhuman Strength,” Bechdel chronicles her susceptibility to exercise fads, including karate, yoga, skiing, biking, running, hiking and mountain climbing.
content: Early in her career, Alison Bechdel, then a cult cartoonist — “at the pinnacle of my bitterness,” she would later say — was invited to contribute to a special gay pride issue of Seattle’s alternative newspaper The Stranger. She fired off a comic strip titled “Oppressed Minority Cartoonist.” She drew herself at her desk, flanked by a bottle of Scotch, mid-tirade. Why had her work been pigeonholed? And why had she complied so willingly, chronicling only lesbians, her “oppressed minority group”? In the last panel, her rant is interrupted by a phone call inviting her to contribute to that very gay pride issue. “I’d be honored,” she capitulates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Robbins and Daniel E. Slotnik
title: U.S. pharmacies are told to offer second vaccine doses to people who got first shots elsewhere.
description: Any residency requirements will be set aside, officials said, allowing college students who got a first shot on campus to get the second while home for the summer.
content: Federal health officials said on Tuesday that they were directing nearly all drugstores and grocery-store pharmacies to offer second doses of Covid-19 vaccines to people who received their first shot from a different provider.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: President Biden announced that fully vaccinated people no longer need to wear masks outdoors in most situations.
content: President Biden and federal officials announced today that fully vaccinated people no longer need to wear masks outdoors in most situations. These include when walking, running, hiking or biking alone, or with members of their household; or if they attend small outdoor gatherings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Proulx
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘They Believe in Ambitious Women. But They Also See the Costs.’
description: In this lesson, students will consider the ways in which teenagers’ political attitudes and beliefs about women in leadership have changed over the past four years.
content: Featured Article: “They Believe in Ambitious Women. But They Also See the Costs.” Text by Claire Cain Miller and photographs by Ruth Fremson
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Everyone Has an Alber Elbaz Story
description: Remembering fashion’s kindest designer.
content: About eight or 10 years ago, back when Alber Elbaz, the Moroccan-born Israeli designer who died on Saturday in Paris at age 59, was still happily ensconced as creative director of Lanvin, I bought a runway sample from the label. It was a gold flapper-like dress I adored, but it was entirely out of my price range unless I bought it used.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: When do we have to wear a mask outside? The C.D.C. says less often, and here’s how and why.
description: Vaccinated people can often skip masks outdoors when they won’t be in crowded situations with strangers, the new guidance says, but unvaccinated people should still wear them in many outdoor settings.
content: The new guidance on mask-wearing from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention on Tuesday says that masks can be shed for some relatively safe outdoor activities, especially by fully vaccinated people, because the virus does not spread readily outdoors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert O'Connell
title: Kyle Pitts Is Set to Be the N.F.L.’s Next Revelation at Tight End
description: After he is drafted Thursday, Pitts is expected to join the N.F.L.’s top-shelf tight ends: Rob Gronkowski, George Kittle and Travis Kelce, big-bodied pass catchers who are coveted by contending teams.
content: In the first quarter of a game against Kentucky last November, the University of Florida coaching staff called a favorite play for a favorite player.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zach Montague
title: Biden will visit Jimmy and Rosalynn Carter while in Georgia commemorating his 100th day in office.
description: Mr. Biden will hold a drive-in rally in Georgia on Thursday and plans to visit the couple after they were unable to attend his inauguration in January because of the coronavirus.
content: President Biden will meet with former President Jimmy Carter and his wife on Thursday as part of a trip punctuating his first 100 days in office, the White House announced on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Kurutz
title: A Barber’s Viral Pandemic Project: Turning His Basement Into a Video Store
description: Frustrated and bored during the pandemic, a Midwestern dad brings his nostalgia for weekend movie rentals to life. Just don’t forget to rewind.
content: Some planted a garden during the pandemic, others decluttered their closets. Brian Hogan, a father of two in suburban Des Moines, Iowa, built a video store in his basement. It was an act of pure whimsy, undertaken “out of necessity and boredom,” Mr. Hogan said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez and Christine Hauser
title: Video Shows Police Laughing at Footage of Arrest of Woman With Dementia
description: The woman, who walked out of a Walmart in Loveland, Colo., without paying for $13.88 worth of items, said in a lawsuit that the police had broken a bone in her arm and dislocated her shoulder.
content: A video released this week shows Colorado police officers laughing at footage of their department’s roadside arrest of a 73-year-old woman with dementia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Goldman and Julian E. Barnes
title: Biden Administration Hopes to Learn Fate of U.S. Hostage in Syria
description: While hopes for the return of Austin Tice have faded, the top American hostage negotiator says he believes the former journalist is still alive.
content: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration pushed hard to free Austin Tice, an American abducted in Syria in 2012. The C.I.A. formed a special cell to gather intelligence, a powerful Persian Gulf ally was enlisted to help and, among other highly unusual personal entreaties, senior officials traveled to Damascus to plead their case with Syria’s top spy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Tesla Makes Money (Including From Selling Cars)
description: Bitcoin and emissions credits helped it set a quarterly earnings record.
content: The electric carmaker posted record quarterly earnings yesterday, beating Wall Street forecasts. But a closer look shows that its core business — you know, making vehicles — wasn’t the only story, and that might be why the company’s stock fell in aftermarket trading.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross
title: A Jane Austen Museum Wants to Discuss Slavery. Will Her Fans Listen?
description: Exhibits at the house where the writer lived in the early 1800s are being updated to add historical context. Not everyone is thrilled.
content: As part of the discussion over racism that followed the police killing of George Floyd in Minneapolis last year, museums have asserted solidarity with the Black Lives Matter movement and begun to rethink and recast how they portray history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sophia June
title: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
description: Recent commercial real estate transactions in New York.
content: $1.905 MILLION
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Erica Chang, Motivated by the Pandemic to Help, Dies at 24
description: Armed with degrees in biomedicine and engineering, she wanted to administer health care. Her Covid-19 death came just five days before her father’s.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Ziwe Endorses Box Braids and ‘Real Housewives’
description: The 29-year-old comedian brings her Instagram and YouTube antics to a prime time Showtime series, “Ziwe,” which premieres May 9.
content: Ziwe, the mononymic master of the viral “gotcha!” moment, swears she isn’t out to get anyone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: The Perfect Playlist
description: Do you like making playlists? What, in your opinion, makes for the perfect mix of songs?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Steinhauer
title: After Failures to Curb Sexual Assault, a Move Toward a Major Shift in Military Law
description: Senator Kirsten Gillibrand has fought for years to remove commanders from deciding assault cases. Now, more colleagues and a Pentagon panel agree.
content: WASHINGTON — After decades of failing to curb sexual assault in the armed forces, lawmakers and Pentagon leaders are poised to make major changes in military laws that many experts have long argued stand in the way of justice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noam Scheiber
title: Biden Orders $15 Minimum Wage for Federal Contractors
description: The current minimum, $10.95, has prevailed since an executive order in 2014, including adjustments in the interim for inflation.
content: President Biden signed an executive order on Tuesday raising the minimum wage paid by federal contractors to $15 an hour, the latest in a set of ambitious pro-labor moves by his administration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson
title: N.Y.P.D. Highway Officer Killed by Drunken Driver, Police Say
description: Anastasio Tsakos was directing traffic on the Long Island Expressway overnight when he was struck by a woman who the police said was intoxicated and driving with a suspended license.
content: A New York City police officer died after being hit by an intoxicated driver early Tuesday on the Long Island Expressway, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Natalie Wynn and Will Wilkinson
description: The April 27 episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
content: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Natalie Wynn and Will Wilkinson. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Draper and Bryan Pietsch
title: Despite new C.D.C. mask guidance, the U.S. patchwork of mandates will take time to unravel.
description: Mask mandates are often the last pandemic public health order to be lifted, as stay-at-home orders and forced business closures become a thing of the past.
content: As the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention offered on Tuesday new guidance about when masks should be worn outdoors, people across the United States are living under an often confusing patchwork of limits, one that could continue for some time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Roni Caryn Rabin
title: C.D.C. Eases Outdoor Mask Guidance for Vaccinated Americans
description: “Go get the shot,” President Biden declared Tuesday, hailing an easing of federal guidance on outdoor mask wearing as a step toward post-pandemic normalcy.
content: WASHINGTON — The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention took a major step on Tuesday toward coaxing Americans into a post-pandemic world, relaxing the rules on mask wearing outdoors as coronavirus cases recede and people increasingly chafe against restrictions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: Travel to the E.U. for vaccinated Americans.
content: The European Commission will recommend a bloc-wide policy change that would allow American tourists fully vaccinated against the coronavirus to visit the E.U. starting this summer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Cottle
title: Biden Underpromises, Overdelivers
description: President Biden has spent his first 100 days focused on the pandemic and the economy — and not much on Twitter.
content: Like any employee, President Biden has to suffer through periodic performance reviews. Thursday marks his 100th day in office — a time-honored if vaguely arbitrary milestone at which a president’s early moves are sliced, diced and spun for all the world to judge. How many bills has he gotten passed? Whom has he appointed? How many executive orders has he signed? Which promises has he broken? Which constituencies has he ticked off?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel
title: Why Iowa Has Become Such a Heartbreaker for Democrats
description: The 2020 carnage for the party was deep in the state, one of many where economic decline and social malaise helped fuel Donald Trump’s rise. Now Democrats face the pivotal question of whether to abandon both Iowa and its first-in-the-nation caucuses.
content: BURLINGTON, Iowa — Tom Courtney and Terry Davis are former factory workers in Des Moines County along the Mississippi River in eastern Iowa, two men of similar age who skipped college but thrived in a community where blue-collar jobs used to be an engine of upward mobility.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Beer, Brussels Sprouts, Bernie Madoff and Today’s G.O.P.
description: Republican pundits and politicians are manufacturing red meat for their followers, regardless of truth.
content: On Friday Larry Kudlow, who was Donald Trump’s top economic adviser, told Fox News viewers that Joe Biden’s climate plans would force Americans to stop eating meat. On July 4, he declared, you’d have to “throw back a plant-based beer with your grilled brussels sprouts.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anahad O'Connor
title: Can you drink alcohol after a Covid-19 vaccine?
description: After a long year and a lot of anticipation, getting the vaccine can be cause for celebration, which for some might mean pouring a drink and toasting to their new immunity. But can alcohol interfere with your immune response?
content: After a long year and a lot of anticipation, getting the vaccine can be cause for celebration, which for some might mean pouring a drink and toasting to their new immunity. But can alcohol interfere with your immune response?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: Shame, Safety and Moving Beyond Cancel Culture
description: When is cancellation useful? And what other tools are available when it isn’t?
content: I’ve been thinking lately about how to move beyond the binary debate over cancel culture. And a good place to start is with the deeper question we’re all trying to ask: What is the kind of politics — the kind of society — we’re trying to achieve in our fights over acceptable speech?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Benner
title: Prosecutors Are Said to Have Sought Aggressive Approach to Capitol Riot Inquiry
description: Their proposal was quashed amid concerns that it would violate First Amendment protections, people briefed on the plan said.
content: WASHINGTON — In the weeks after the deadly Capitol riot on Jan. 6, federal prosecutors in Washington devised a broad plan to root out possible conspirators, according to two people briefed on it: pull together the names of an array of people who may have known the assailants, and investigate them for ties to the attack.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Knoll
title: N.H.L. and Turner Sports Reach 7-Year Media Rights Deal
description: Turner Sports will broadcast half of each year’s playoffs and three Stanley Cup finals, and plans to bring games to the HBO Max streaming service.
content: The N.H.L. solidified its future on television and multimedia platforms in the United States on Tuesday with the announcement of a second broadcast rights deal that will take effect after its agreement with NBC expires after this season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: How Do You Interact With News on Social Media?
description: We’d like to get your responses to a few headlines, and ask a couple of brief follow-up questions.
content: Social media has become an important way that many people find, consume and share news. These online communities expose us to information we might not otherwise come across, and provide a space for discussion and exchange.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: To Understand Tech, Look Beyond the C.E.O.s
description: What the tech barons think matters. But imagine if those working in the trenches had a bigger voice.
content: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: John C. Martin, 69, Dies; Led Drugmaker in Breakthroughs
description: A chemist by training, he turned Gilead Sciences into a leading, and lucrative, innovator with single-pill treatments for H.I.V. and hepatitis C.
content: John C. Martin, who became a billionaire by developing and marketing a daily single-dose pill that transformed H.I.V. into a manageable disease and who popularized another drug that cures hepatitis C, died on March 30 in Palo Alto, Calif. He was 69.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Wang and Joy Dong
title: A Graying China May Have to Put Off Retirement. Workers Aren’t Happy.
description: Most Chinese workers retire by 60. But with the population aging and pension funds running low, the government says that must change.
content: For Meng Shan, a 48-year-old urban management worker in the Chinese city of Nanchang, retirement can’t come soon enough.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Calum Marsh
title: ‘Best Summer Ever’ Review: Not Just Another Song and Dance
description: A largely disabled cast leads this charming teen musical.
content: “Best Summer Ever” is a high school musical. It isn’t “High School Musical” — it’s better. Tender and exuberant, it includes set pieces modeled on “Footloose” and “Grease,” and feels closer to those films in spirit than to the Disney Channel. This is the kind of movie that vibrates with the energy of the people who made it, whose enthusiasm radiates from the screen. The actors and filmmakers seemed to have had an extremely good time bringing “Best Summer Ever” to life. Watching it made me happy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck
title: New York Mayoral Race Begins a New Phase: The TV Ad Blitz
description: As the candidates seek to attract voters’ attention, an ad for Scott Stringer says he is the candidate best suited to lead the “city’s greatest comeback.”
content: The ad wars in the New York City mayor’s race are officially on.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: Chair Incident Was Sign of Enduring Sexism, E.U. Leader Says
description: “Would this have happened if I had worn a suit and a tie?” asked Ursula von der Leyen, president of the European Commission, after she was left standing during a summit in Turkey this month.
content: It was an awkward diplomatic moment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: In a Locked-Down Capitol, Biden Will Address a Sparse Audience
description: Strict security and health restrictions will lend a surreal mood to President Biden’s first address to a joint session of Congress, with only 200 people attending instead of the usual 1,600.
content: WASHINGTON — Congressional officials have ramped up security and drastically limited the number of attendees for President Biden’s first joint address to Congress on Wednesday, preparing the Capitol for the long-awaited speech under the strictures of a pandemic and a heightened threat level after the deadly Jan. 6 riot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Oleg Kashin
title: Aleksei Navalny Is Russia’s True Leader
description: Brave, proud and unbroken, he is standing up to an inhumane system.
content: In 2003, four years into President Vladimir Putin’s tenure and with liberal politics at a nadir, I visited the Moscow office of the center-left Yabloko Party. There, among the 50-something inveterate anti-communists who dominated the party, sat a 27-year-old staff member. It was Aleksei Navalny.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: Census (Barely) Leads to a Congressional Loss for New York
description: Even so, the state's congressional delegation remains powerful, and redistricting could help preserve a Democratic majority in the U.S. House.
content: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marie Fazio
title: How Mask Guidelines Have Evolved
description: Officials offered mixed messages about masks in the early days of the coronavirus pandemic before embracing them as a simple but effective tool for slowing the spread of Covid-19.
content: A lot has changed since early 2020, when countries around the world first realized the potential threat of a highly contagious, and still mysterious, flulike virus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Workers at Exclusive Montana Resort Reach $1 Million Wage Settlement
description: A group of guest workers from Jamaica had accused the Yellowstone Club and Hospitality Staffing Solutions of shortchanging their wages and tips.
content: Dozens of guest workers from Jamaica have reached a $1 million settlement in a lawsuit that accused an exclusive Montana ski resort — home to business titans and Hollywood celebrities — of shortchanging their tips and wages and discriminating against them, court records show.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor and Christina Morales
title: Epicurious Has a Beef With Beef
description: The popular cooking website will not publish new beef recipes over concerns about climate change. “We think of this decision as not anti-beef but rather pro-planet,” an article said.
content: Could an empire of the kitchen quietly stop cooking with beef and leave no one the wiser?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Coscarelli
title: Britney Spears Asks to Address Court Overseeing Her Conservatorship
description: A lawyer for the singer told the judge presiding in her case that Spears was seeking to speak to the court on an “expedited basis.”
content: Britney Spears has something to say.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: Any eligible adult in New York will be able to walk in for vaccination at state-run sites.
description: Starting Thursday, anyone 16 or older can get a first dose of a Covid vaccine without an appointment at any state-run mass vaccination site in New York, a policy the state hopes will draw out the hesitant.
content: All state-run mass coronavirus vaccination sites in New York will allow anyone 16 or older to walk in without an appointment and get their first dose, beginning on Thursday, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo announced on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Creswell
title: Starbucks says its U.S. sales have made a ‘full recovery.’
description: Starbucks made a profit of $659 million in the first three months of the year as quarantine restrictions were eased.
content: Seeing signs that customers are eager to gather and put the dark days of the pandemic behind them, the coffee giant Starbucks said that its sales in the United States made a “full recovery” in the first three months of the year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt
title: Second Close Call Between Iranian and American Vessels Raises Tensions
description: The tense encounters come as the two countries have resumed talks over renewing the 2015 nuclear agreement. The latest episode ended only after an American warship fired warning shots.
content: WASHINGTON — For the second time in a month, vessels from Iran and the United States came dangerously close in the Persian Gulf on Monday night, the Navy said on Tuesday, escalating tensions between the two nations as their negotiators have resumed talks toward renewing the 2015 nuclear deal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler and Jennifer Medina
title: How Gavin Newsom Landed in a California Jam
description: The campaign to recall the state’s governor shows that even a one-party stronghold like California can be rocked by the nation’s political polarization.
content: SACRAMENTO — For all the controversies and Covid-19 crises that now have Gov. Gavin Newsom of California facing a historic recall election, it was a pair of prosaic events on Nov. 6 — a court hearing and a dinner — that led to the current political instability that will grip the state for months to come.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Lythcott-Haims
title: Is There Really Such a Thing as Maternal Instinct?
description: In “Mom Genes,” Abigail Tucker attempts to uncover the science behind what makes a mother and reveals her own struggle to be a good one.
content: MOM GENESInside the New Science of Our Ancient Maternal InstinctBy Abigail Tucker
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
title: For U.K.’s Johnson, Plenty of Mud but Will It Stick?
description: Accusations of lying, cronyism and intemperate talk emerge seemingly on a daily basis, but there’s little evidence yet that Britons care.
content: LONDON — Prime Minister Boris Johnson has long had a weakness for a funny line, even in the face of an unfunny problem like the pandemic. When coronavirus cases first spiked last spring, he promised that a lockdown would “squash the sombrero.” When he spoke to businesspeople about an emergency plan to manufacture ventilators, he joked that it could be called “Operation Last Gasp.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Did Emma Sulkowicz Get Redpilled?
description: At the very least, she’s found a new social set.
content: At the very least, she’s found a new social set.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Surviving It All
description: She’s 92, made it through the Holocaust, and set off for a cruise around the world in February 2020.
content: She’s 92, made it through the Holocaust, and set off for a cruise around the world in February 2020.

title: How Podcasts Learned to Speak
description: The once useless-seeming medium that became essential.

description: The very real, totally bizarre bucatini shortage of 2020.
content: The very real, totally bizarre bucatini shortage of 2020.

description: Have you been paying attention to the news recently? See how many of these 10 questions you can get right.

author: By Sasha von Oldershausen
title: No Cars on Sidewalks. Unless You’re N.Y.P.D.
description: I live in Jamaica, down the block from a police station house. Each day, officers park their personal and squad cars on sidewalks, frustrating residents.
content: I live in Jamaica, down the block from a police station house. Each day, officers park their personal and squad cars on sidewalks, frustrating residents.

title: In Astoria, West African Food and Groceries to Go
description: The cooking at Nneji is largely drawn from Nigeria, but many of the dishes are shared by other countries.
content: The cooking at Nneji is largely drawn from Nigeria, but many of the dishes are shared by other countries.

description: During the pandemic, a barber from Des Moines built an old-school video store in his basement.

title: Watch Live: Biden Delivers Remarks on Coronavirus
description: President Biden will deliver remarks on the coronavirus response. He is expected to speak about outdoor mask mandates.
content: President Biden will deliver remarks on the coronavirus response. He is expected to speak about outdoor mask mandates.

author: By The New York Times
title: Off-Roaders Narrowly Escape Wildfire
description: Laurie Glass and friends out driving Jeeps in Arizona’s Hualapai Mountains on Sunday got caught in the Flag Fire, which has grown to hundreds of acres and forced hundreds of people from their homes.
content: Laurie Glass and friends out driving Jeeps in Arizona’s Hualapai Mountains on Sunday got caught in the Flag Fire, which has grown to hundreds of acres and forced hundreds of people from their homes.

author: By The Associated Press
title: Biden Sets $15 Minimum Wage for Federal Contractors
description: President Biden on Tuesday signed an executive order to increase the minimum wage to $15 an hour for federal contractors starting in 2022.
content: President Biden on Tuesday signed an executive order to increase the minimum wage to $15 an hour for federal contractors starting in 2022.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Improvement Association, Chapter Five: ‘Democrat, Republican, White, Black, Green’
description: The Bladen Improvement PAC faces a new challenge — but how new is it really?
content: In this episode: The Bladen Improvement PAC’s power is threatened when an unlikely candidate enters the race for county commissioner. People outside the PAC are starting to make clear that they have their own ideas about how to build Black political power in the county.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: April 27, 2021
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, April 27, 2021.
content: An article on Sunday about C.E.O. compensation during the pandemic misstated the reason Robert A. Iger’s compensation fell in 2020. It was entirely because of the difficult year at the Walt Disney Company. His move from chief executive to executive chairman was not a factor.
source.name: The New York Times
